passage_text: Included is a guide to the average salaries offered in IT jobs that have cited Support Analyst in their job title over the 3 months to 15 October 2015 with a comparison to the same period in the previous 2 years. The table below looks at the demand and provides a guide to the average salaries quoted in IT jobs citing Support Analyst within the UK over the 3 months to 15 October 2015.
$82,000. Average Technical Support Analyst salaries for job postings nationwide are 42% higher than average salaries for all job postings nationwide.

Support Analyst Salary. Support Analyst average salary is $66,009, median salary is $65,000 with a salary range from $21,549 to $176,800. Support Analyst salaries are collected from government agencies and companies. Each salary is associated with a real job position.

For example the median expected annual pay for a typical Technical Support Analyst I in the United States is $54,898 so 50% of the people who perform the job of Technical Support Analyst I in the United States are expected to make less than $54,898. Source: HR Reported data as of October 2015. Median $54,898. The annual salary for someone with the job title Technical Support Analyst I may vary depending on a number of factors including industry, company size, location, years of experience and level of education.

Home It, Support Analyst Salary. It, Support Analyst average salary is $68,270, median salary is $69,718 with a salary range from $36,750 to $100,000. It, Support Analyst salaries are collected from government agencies and companies. Each salary is associated with a real job position.

After working for 10 to 20 years, Information Technology Support Analysts make a median salary of $59K. People who have worked for more than 20 years report a median income of $61K, which is barely higher than the median for folks with 10 to 20 years of experience. A support information technology (IT) analyst is responsible for much of the day-to-day technical support and development in a business or corporate setting. These analysts respond to problems and complaints from other departments regarding the quality of their technological systems (such as computers and phones).
